newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bonds end flat, concerns around measures.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bonds end flat, concerns around measures.

text.p: Argentine bonds finished flat Thursday after another session spent worrying about the political will to push through measures aimed at reversing the widening budget deficit.
The 5.5 percent dollar-denominated Bocon Previsional 2 due 2001 was flat at 114.50. Argentina's FRB due 2005 rose 3/8 to 77.00.
Initially the market was unnerved by growing concerns that the economic measures, mainly including tax increases unveiled a couple of weeks ago, would not be passed in full by Congress.
Government officials have been warning that delays in Congress in passing the measures could result in less savings than the $1.2 billion the package was seeking to make.

Still, Economy Minister Roque Fernandez said Thursday he will seek to cut $1.0 billion in spending by year's end. Market players have been hoping for actual expenditure cuts rather than increased revenue through tax hikes.
Despite all the market concerns surrounding the measures, a bond analyst with a large Argentine bank said "in the end, these measures should help the fiscal front, which is good for bonds."
And, a trader predicted that "the market will find a floor and stay there until the measures are passed."
In the money markets, one day call money was unchanged at 9.75 percent.
